page.title: 18NATURE IN LONGSTANTON
page.content: Amidst such intensive farming it would be odd if we had any unusual flora or fauna. We have no Nature Reserve or Site of Special Scientific Interest, but we do have much we think encouraging. Bats are back in the High Street. Less spraying means poppies again in the verges. Cowslips have re-appeared: we protect two in our school lawn. There are minnows and stone-loach in the brook, and frogs again around our school pond. Kestrels are common. So are newts, if one knows where to look. Rabbits again abound in the fields once called Coney Hill. Foxes are a nuisance: one raids the dustbins in Haddows Close. Sadly, Dutch Elm disease is killing all the fine elms in our village, but other trees are already planted and will one day take their place.
